I got into science by doing a degree in psychology
and that degree is quite biologically oriented.

28.text:
I became more and more interested in the brain,
and decided to do a PhD in neuroscience.

34.text:
I'm a professor of physics. I research and
lecture in physics in Cambridge.

38.text:
My actual area of research is what's known
as 'soft matter physics' which is pretty much

43.text:
the physics of everyday stuff like food, animals,
plants and plastics.

It's only when I left school at the age of
18 and started to work in labs and then do

Having a female physics teacher at my school
was really important, because it enabled me

85.text:

89.text:
I think it was rather a surprise to my family
that this is what I wanted to do.

93.text:
The idea that a girl could want to do physics
is just not talked about enough.

97.text:
The Royal Society was founded over 350 years
ago. It was only men doing science and philosophy around then.

anyone wrote down women could not become Fellows,

Society was organised in ways that implicitly
were sexist. Women would not have been expected

119.text:
to be engaged in discussion in public places
- that would have been seen as rather odd.

168.text:

claim to have discovered something. The trouble

174.text:

Society journals, you needed an FRS - a Fellow

179.text:

work. If you were a woman and not moving in those circles it must have been much harder.
